column2: Cumulative EU offshore goals of installed capacity: 60 GW by 2030 and 300 GW by 2050
column5: The implementation of TA2.38 is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.1, as the development of offshore wind energy can contribute to the protection of biodiversity and ecosystems, and the creation of marine protected areas can help to preserve and restore natural habitats.

column2: Cumulative EU offshore goals of installed capacity: 60 GW by 2030 and 300 GW by 2050
column5: The implementation of TA2.38 can also have a positive impact on TA6.9, as the reduction of chemical pesticides and the promotion of sustainable agriculture practices can help to reduce the risk and use of chemical pesticides, and the development of offshore wind energy can contribute to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.

column2: The strategy sets targets for an installed capacity of at least 1 GW of ocean energy by 2030 and 40 GW by 2050
column5: The implementation of TA2.39 is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.1, as the development of ocean energy can contribute to the protection of biodiversity and ecosystems, and the creation of marine protected areas can help to preserve and restore natural habitats.

column2: Around 30% of EU primary steel production is expected to be decarbonised on the basis of renewable hydrogen.
column5: The implementation of TA2.40 can have a positive impact on TA3.9, as the use of renewable hydrogen in steel production can help to reduce the processing capacity of strategic raw materials and increase the recycling of materials.

column2: Halve the amount of residual (non-recycled) municipal waste by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA3.1 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.13, as the reduction of municipal waste can help to increase the recycling capacity of strategic raw materials and reduce the need for primary materials.

column2: Double EU’s circular material use rate in the coming decade
column5: The implementation of TA3.3 can have a positive impact on TA3.9, as the increase in circular material use can help to reduce the processing capacity of strategic raw materials and increase the recycling of materials.

column2: By 2030, Union extraction capacity should be able of extracting the ores, minerals or concentrates needed to produce at least 10% of the Union’s annual consumption of strategic raw materials
column5: The implementation of TA3.8 may have a negative impact on TA3.9, as the increase in extraction capacity can lead to an increase in the processing capacity of strategic raw materials, potentially reducing the recycling of materials.

column2: By 2030, Union processing capacity, including for all intermediate processing steps, should be able of producing at least 40% of the Union’s annual consumption of strategic raw materials
column5: The implementation of TA3.9 can have a positive impact on TA3.13, as the increase in processing capacity can help to increase the recycling capacity of strategic raw materials and reduce the need for primary materials.

column2: Diversify the Union’s imports of strategic raw materials with a view to ensuring that, by 2030, the Union’s annual consumption of each strategic raw material at any relevant stage of processing can rely on imports from several third countries or from overseas countries or territories (OCTs) and that no third country accounts for more than 65% of the Union’s annual consumption of such a strategic raw material
column5: The implementation of TA3.11 can have a positive impact on TA3.9, as the diversification of imports can help to reduce the dependence on a single supplier and increase the security of supply of strategic raw materials, potentially increasing the recycling of materials.

column2: By 2030, manufacturing capacity in the Union of the strategic net-zero technologies listed in the Annex approaches or reaches a benchmark of at least 40% of the Union’s annual deployment needs
column5: The implementation of TA3.12 can have a positive impact on TA3.9, as the increase in manufacturing capacity can help to increase the recycling capacity of strategic raw materials and reduce the need for primary materials.

column2: By 2030, Union recycling capacity, including for all intermediate recycling steps, should be able of producing at least 25% of the Union’s annual consumption of strategic raw materials and should be able of recycling significantly increasing amounts of each strategic raw material from waste
column5: The implementation of TA3.13 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.1, as the increase in recycling capacity can help to reduce the amount of municipal waste and increase the recycling of materials.

column2: Producers of starting, lighting and ignition batteries, industrial batteries and electric vehicle batteries or, where appointed in accordance with Article 57(1), producer responsibility organisations, shall take back, free of charge and without an obligation on the end-user to buy a new battery, nor to have bought the battery from them, and shall ensure that all waste starting, lighting and ignition batteries, waste industrial batteries and waste electric vehicle batteries regardless of their nature, chemical composition, condition, brand, or origin of the respective category that they have made available on the market for the first time in the territory of that Member State are collected separately
column5: The implementation of TA3.15 can have a positive impact on TA3.13, as the collection of waste batteries can help to increase the recycling capacity of strategic raw materials and reduce the need for primary materials.

column2: Producers of portable batteries or, where appointed in accordance with Article 57(1), producer responsibility organisations, shall attain, and maintain durably, at least the following collection targets for waste portable batteries: - 45% by 31 December 2023
column7: The implementation of TA3.16 can have a positive impact on TA3.13, as the collection of waste portable batteries can help to increase the recycling capacity of strategic raw materials and reduce the need for primary materials.

column2: Producers of LMT batteries or, where appointed in accordance with Article 57(1), producer responsibility organisations, shall attain, and maintain durably, at least the following collection targets of waste LMT batteries: - 51% by 31 December 2028
column6: The implementation of TA3.17 can have a positive impact on TA3.13, as the collection of waste LMT batteries can help to increase the recycling capacity of strategic raw materials and reduce the need for primary materials.

column2: For industrial batteries with a capacity greater than 2kWh, except those with exclusively external storage, electric vehicle batteries and starting, lighting and ignition batteries that contain cobalt, lead, lithium or nickel in active materials, the minimum recycled content percentage for each battery model per year and per manufacturing plant shall be: From 18 August 2031, 16% cobalt
column5: and 6% nickel
column12: The implementation of TA3.18 can have a positive impact on TA3.13, as the increase in recycled content can help to increase the recycling capacity of strategic raw materials and reduce the need for primary materials.

column2: Any natural or legal person that places on the market products incorporating portable batteries shall ensure that those batteries are readily removable and replaceable by the end-user at any time during the lifetime of the product
column5: The implementation of TA3.19 can have a positive impact on TA3.13, as the design of products for recyclability can help to increase the recycling capacity of strategic raw materials and reduce the need for primary materials.

column2: Recycling shall achieve at least the following targets for recycling efficiency: No later than 31 December 2025 - 75% by average weight of lead-acid batteries
column3: - 80% by average weight of nickel-cadmium batteries - 50% by average weight of other waste batteries No later than 31 December 2030 - 80% by average weight of lead-acid batteries
column6: The implementation of TA3.20 can have a positive impact on TA3.13, as the increase in recycling efficiency can help to increase the recycling capacity of strategic raw materials and reduce the need for primary materials.

column2: Recycling shall achieve at least the following targets for recycling efficiency: - No later than 31 December 2025, 65% by average weight of lithium-based batteries
column3: - No later than 31 December 2030, 70% by average weight of lithium-based batteries
column6: The implementation of TA3.21 can have a positive impact on TA3.13, as the increase in recycling efficiency can help to increase the recycling capacity of strategic raw materials and reduce the need for primary materials.

column2: All recycling shall achieve at least the following targets for recovery of materials: - No later than 31 December 2027, 90% for cobalt, copper, lead, nickel
column3: - No later than 31 December 2031, 95% for cobalt, copper, lead, nickel
column6: The implementation of TA3.22 can have a positive impact on TA3.13, as the increase in recovery of materials can help to increase the recycling capacity of strategic raw materials and reduce the need for primary materials.

column2: Food security: Ensuring food security and access to quality, safe, sustainable, nutritious food for all
column5: The implementation of TA5.32 can have a positive impact on TA3.3, as the increase in food security can help to reduce the amount of food waste and increase the recycling of materials.

column2: Nutrition and healthy, sustainable diets: Move to healthier and more sustainable diets
column5: The implementation of TA5.33 can have a positive impact on TA3.3, as the promotion of healthy and sustainable diets can help to reduce the amount of food waste and increase the recycling of materials.

column2: Health impact of diets: Reversing of the rise in overweight and obesity rates across the EU by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA5.34 can have a positive impact on TA3.3, as the reduction of overweight and obesity rates can help to reduce the amount of food waste and increase the recycling of materials.

column2: 1.a Legally protect a minimum of 30% of the EU’s land area
column5: The implementation of TA6.1 may have a negative impact on TA2.38, as the protection of land areas can limit the development of offshore wind energy and reduce the installed capacity.

column2: 1.b Legally protect a minimum of 30% of the EU's sea area
column5: The implementation of TA6.2 may have a negative impact on TA2.38, as the protection of sea areas can limit the development of offshore wind energy and reduce the installed capacity.

column2: 2.a Strictly protect at least a third of the EU'S protected areas
column5: The implementation of TA6.3 may have a negative impact on TA2.38, as the strict protection of protected areas can limit the development of offshore wind energy and reduce the installed capacity.

column2: 2b. Strictly protect all remaining EU primary and old-growth forests
column5: The implementation of TA6.4 may have a negative impact on TA2.40, as the strict protection of primary and old-growth forests can limit the availability of biomass for decarbonization of steel production.

column2: 4. By 2030, significant areas of degraded and carbon-rich ecosystems are restored
column5: The implementation of TA6.7 can have a positive impact on TA2.40, as the restoration of degraded ecosystems can help to increase the availability of biomass for decarbonization of steel production.

column2: 5. The decline of pollinators is reversed (the target is in common with "A New Deal for Pollinators")
column5: The implementation of TA6.8 can have a positive impact on TA5.33, as the reversal of the decline of pollinators can help to promote healthy and sustainable diets.

column2: 6. The risk and use of chemical pesticides is reduced by 50%, and the use of more hazardous pesticides is reduced by 50%
column5: The implementation of TA6.9 can have a positive impact on TA5.33, as the reduction of chemical pesticides can help to promote healthy and sustainable diets.

column2: 7. At least 10% of agricultural area is under high-diversity landscape features
column5: The implementation of TA6.10 can have a positive impact on TA5.33, as the promotion of high-diversity landscape features can help to promote healthy and sustainable diets.

column2: 9. Three billion trees are planted in the EU, in full respect of ecological principles
column5: The implementation of TA6.11 can have a positive impact on TA6.7, as the planting of trees can help to restore degraded ecosystems.

column2: 11. At least 25.000 km of free-flowing rivers are restored
column5: The implementation of TA6.13 can have a positive impact on TA6.7, as the restoration of free-flowing rivers can help to restore degraded ecosystems.

column2: 12. There is a 50% reduction in the number of Red List species threatened by Invasive Alien Species (IAS)
column5: The implementation of TA6.14 can have a positive impact on TA6.8, as the reduction of IAS can help to reverse the decline of pollinators.

column2: 13. The losses of nutrients from fertilisers are reduced by 50%, resulting in the reduction of the use of fertilisers by at least 20%
column5: The implementation of TA6.15 can have a positive impact on TA6.9, as the reduction of nutrient losses can help to reduce the use of chemical pesticides.
